suchin writings

The Determinant

28 Feb 2017

Perhaps one of the most important concepts of linear algebra is that of the determinant. Most students learn about the determinant as an aside to more interesting topics, but in reality the determinant is a fundamental idea that defines how we solve linear systems. This post will define the determinant and why it is useful.

Most students have seen the following linear system of equations in high school algebra:

where are unknown, are oonstants, and are coefficients. The classic problem is to solve for .

But there could exist many solutions to a linear system, or none at all. Formally, a linear system can be compatible (have at least one solution) or incompatible (have no solution). Furthermore, a compatible system can be determinate (have a unique solution) or indeterminate (have more than one solution). We use determinants to identify compatible, determinate systems of which there is one unique solution.

To see more concretely where the determinant comes in when solving linear systems, see the following two dimensional system:

Using the usual method, we solve for and :

The determinant is essentially the formalized study of the denominators of this equation. We will prove that a system of linear equations has a unique solution if and only if the determinant is not zero.
